ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The class was very geometric, which I'm not used to and was hard for me. I'm glad that I got an introduction to this powerful perspective.
I learned how to better structure a math presentation, and the basics of representation theory.
I definitely developed my skills at math presentation and understanding math talks.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength was that individual projects allowed students to study what they were interested in. I wish we had done less category theory, or maybe used it in a homework. It was a bit too abstract for me to understand without practice problems.

This course was good at improving presentation style. However, some aspects of the course were quite frustrating. In particular, nothing was really proved; every theorem or proposition was left to us to "check the details" when really the entire content of the proof is in the "details".

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I enjoyed the class. The homework sessions and presentations were sometimes frustrating but I think really improved my presentation skills.
Take If you are interested in learning about representation theory from a mathematical perspective. It can very abstract for people who have seen representations in physics.
Representation theory is a great subject, I would highly recommend taking it.
